column26: Re: adaptation, many species in the system have wide environmental ranges (e.g., giant kelp and other algae) that likely enhances their resistance to environmental change. Kelp forests in northern portion of southern CA include mixes of temperate and tropical species that likely enhance resistance of functional groups.
column36: Adaptation... biogenic species (giant kelp) designed for the most common perturbation (ocean swell). Individuals in nutrient rich depth refuge allow for re-population of shallower decimated portion of population. This occurs on larger spatial scales for species with more open populations (fishes and inverts). There is sufficient regional variation in environmental conditions relative to scales of connectivity to allow re-population across area of perturbation.

column10: Typhoons - species assemblages appear to be an important factor that influenced their quick resilience to the storm or their quick recovery.     For war and shrimp ponds, humans initially outplanted the deforested/degraded areas, but then hydrology and propagules did the rest.     Surface accretion rates we have measured using radionuclides in several mangroves in Vietnam and Palau (and colleagues have sampled using rSETS in Kosrae and Pohnpei) appear to be keeping up with SLR. This is inpart attributed to healthy, intact forests continuing to produce roots and in part to the high sediment loads some of these high islands receive.
